Award.AwardTitle: OCE-PRF Track 1 (Broadening Participation): The influence of predator-prey interactions on climate-induced range shifts in marine communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Trawl surveys conducted over the last 40 years have provided evidence that warming ocean temperatures have driven widespread shifts in the distribution of marine species in the coastal United States, with some species shifting north by more than 200 km. However, not all species have responded at the same rate to these changes in ocean temperatures. As a result, warming could alter key species interactions (such as competition or predation) that could mediate the capacity for these populations to respond to future climate change as well as impact the goods and services provided to humans by these ecosystems, including commercial and recreational fisheries. In this research project, the fellow will examine the influence of predator-prey interactions on regional species shifts related to changes in ocean temperatures. In addition, the fellow will use the results of the research to develop educational materials and an interactive app for the Rutgers Summer Science Program. The activities the fellow will develop for the program have the potential to contribute directly to broadening the participation of under-represented groups in ocean sciences.

Most current models predicting range shifts in response to climate change consider each species in isolation. However, predator-prey interactions have the potential to modify the capacity for species to respond to changes in climate. Indeed, invasions by exotic species have been found to be more rapid where populations are released from natural enemies (e.g. ?enemy release?) and are slowed by the presence of predators that resist their establishment (e.g. ?biotic resistance?). This research will demonstrate the degree to which these key concepts from invasion biology apply to climate-induced range shifts and need to be considered when projecting future range shifts. The fellow will utilize a 45-year dataset on predator and prey distributions and ocean temperatures on the U.S. Northeast Shelf. The role of enemy release and biotic resistance will be tested by examining the effect of predator abundance and predator-prey spatial overlap on the rate at which prey populations respond to shifting climates. Fisheries will be considered as human predators. In addition, the fellow will test the direct effect of warming on the overlap between predator and prey. Using these relationships from historical data, range shifts will be projected for future climate scenarios, with and without changes in predator abundance that might result due to fishing. Improving our predictions of range shifts will be critical to forecasting how marine biodiversity, ecosystem functioning, and fisheries will be affected by climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Warming ocean temperatures are leading to shifts in species distributions as organisms track changes in preferred temperatures. However, variation in those thermal preferences can alter the rate at which species move in response to warming, leading to mismatches that can alter species interactions. In particular, asymmetries in the responses of predator and prey to climate change can modify their spatial overlap and the likelihood of spatial refugia for prey. In this project, I evaluated the effect of ocean warming on spatial overlap between four piscivores and their prey on the U.S. Northeast Shelf. For Atlantic cod, a historically important piscivore in this system, warming led to a decline in overlap with its prey and a potential reduction in its ability to exert top-down control. In contrast, the warmer water affinity of spiny dogfish led to enhanced overlap with prey, expanding their importance as predators in the ecosystem. Taken together, warming will exacerbate the declines in ecological role of cod but this loss may be counteracted by increases in dominance of piscivores with contrasting thermal preferences. Our results suggest warming has the potential to drive major changes in individual predator-prey interactions by altering overlap among species. However, diversity in thermal affinity among piscivores may buffer against warming impacts on marine ecosystems. As such, warming impacts on predator-prey interactions will need to be considered in conjunction with measures of diversity to more accurately forecast how ecosystem functioning and ecosystem services will be affected by climate change. This finding is likely to be relevant to understanding impacts of climate change on food webs across marine and terrestrial ecosystems.

 

Broader Impacts:

The project supported several projects that contributed directly to broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in ocean sciences. In conjunction with the Rutgers 4-H STEM Ambassador program, I developed a day-long intensive science experience to introduce 9-10 high school students from backgrounds underserved and underrepresented in STEM fields in 2016, and 2017. The primary research results from my OCE fellowship were adapted in an interactive game for students to simulate shifting species distributions along the east coast of the United States. Students report having a greater understanding of climate change and interest in aquatic science careers as a result of this programming. To create an opportunity for a more sustained interaction with students, I designed and implemented a Marine Science Internship at New Brunswick High School. Three students participated in the program and were introduced to the physical basis for climate change, the tools scientists use to study these changes, and the impacts of ocean acidification, sea level rise, sea ice melt, and species distribution shifts on marine ecosystems.  Students report having greater exposure to the diversity of marine careers available, and that their interest in this careers has increased. Finally, to broaden the reach of these educational activities, I collaborated with DataSpire and NPR’s Science Friday to use the shifting fishes game as the basis for a series of data-based, digital, educational resources for informal and formal audiences around the world. These modules will be launched in March 2018 at https://www.sciencefriday.com/educate/.
